newsitem.title: UK: British Aerospace first-half profits rise.
newsitem.headline: British Aerospace first-half profits rise.

text.p: Pre-tax profits at British Aerospace Plc, a manufacturer of commercial and military aircraft, jumped nearly 75 percent to 199 million pounds ($309 million) during the first six months of 1996, reflecting strong orders and better profitability.
"We have got real growth, margins improving, a very strong order book and we are generating cash," said finance director Richard Lapthorne in an interview Thursday.
Underlying profits, before exceptional charges, rose 38 percent to 215 million pounds ($334 million) for the first half of the year.
"The figures did come in above forecasts," said industry analyst Paul Pickford at Panmure Gordon, brokers in London. "There was an upbeat statement and better cash position than expected," he said.

Lapthorne said the company was also pleased with the net cash position of 511 million pounds ($795 million) at the end of June. He said the company had feared a stronger draw on cash now it is building another batch of Tornado fighter bombers for Saudi Arabia.

Meanwhile, chief executive Sir Richard Evans said the group's strong performance was set to continue, thanks to increased productivity and a 13 billion pound ($20 billion) order book, including defence orders worth 9.2 billion pounds ($14 billion).
The defence business increased its first half profits to 255 million pounds ($397 million) from 240 million ($373 million) a year ago on sales of 2.2 billion pounds ($3.4 billion).

The company's commercial aerospace division turned in another loss in the first half, with continuing problems at its Jetstream turboprop aircraft business taking profits from making wings for the four-nation Airbus Industrie consortium.
